hawaiian_text: A pau ka pule ‘ana a Nāmakaokapāo‘o, i ia wā i  ‘o‘oki ai ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi i luna pono o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o, e ho‘ohuli aku ā nā ‘oi o ke ko‘i  iā Puali‘i, moku ke po‘o, a ‘ōlelo mai i kahi ‘ē. Pane  mai ke po‘o o Puali‘i iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Aloha  ‘oe, e Nāmakaokapāo‘o.” Lālau akula ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke po‘o o Puali‘i a kiola akula i  kai o Waipouli, he ana ma kahakai o Honouliuli, ‘o  kona loa, ‘elima mile ka loa.
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_translation: The prayer of Nāmakaokapāo‘o was completed at that time, when he sought the ko‘ilipi on the pono of Nāmakaokapāo‘o, to transfer the sacredness of the ko‘i to Puali‘i, the island of the sacred, and speak from another place. The head of Puali‘i was placed upon Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Hello to you, O Nāmakaokapāo‘o.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o also served the head of Puali‘i and the kai of Waipouli, which is in the area of Honouliuli, his loa, five miles the loa.
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_commentary:
**Paragraph 9:**  
• This passage describes a ritualistic or symbolic act involving the transfer of sacredness ("‘oi") and the placement of a "po‘o" (head) onto Nāmakaokapāo‘o, reflecting themes of spiritual authority and ancestral connections. The phrase "e ho‘ohuli aku ā nā ‘oi o ke ko‘i iā Puali‘i" suggests a deliberate act of transferring sacred power from the "ko‘i" (possibly a deity or ritual object) to Puali‘i, emphasizing the interplay between human and divine realms.  
• "Ko‘ilipi" and "kai o Waipouli" are likely place names, with "kai" (sea/coast) and "po‘o" (head) serving as symbolic markers of sacred geography. "Honouliuli" is a known historical region in O‘ahu, linking the narrative to specific Hawaiian cultural landscapes.  
• The dialogue “Aloha ‘oe, e Nāmakaokapāo‘o” (Hello to you, O Nāmakaokapāo‘o) mirrors traditional Hawaiian greetings that acknowledge both the speaker’s identity and the sacredness of the recipient, possibly signifying a rite of passage or spiritual recognition.  
• The phrase “five miles the loa” may allude to the "loa" (sacred or long) as a metaphor for distance or spiritual reach, tying to the concept of *mo‘olele* (distance) in Hawaiian cosmology. It could also reference the *loa* (spirits) in ancestral veneration, where physical proximity (e.g., five miles) symbolizes a boundary between the living and the spiritual.  
• The act of "pane mai ke po‘o o Puali‘i" (placing the head of Puali‘i) may allegorically represent the acceptance of responsibility or the embodiment of a deity’s power. In Hawaiian tradition, the "po‘o" (head) is a symbol of leadership and divine authority, suggesting Nāmakaokapāo‘o is now spiritually empowered by Puali‘i.  
• The mention of "kai o Waipouli" (sea of Waipouli) and "kahakai o Honouliuli" (area of Honouliuli) highlights the significance of coastal and valley regions in Hawaiian mythology, often associated with *mo‘okūau* (sacred sites) and ancestral journeys.  
• The structure of the sentence mirrors earlier examples in the text, where names are broken into poetic components (e.g., "Nāmakaokapāo‘o" as *Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o*, "the eyes of the pāo‘o fish"), reinforcing the tradition of *kī‘ōpae* (proverbial expressions) and *mele* (chant) in Hawaiian storytelling.  
• The reference to "ko‘i" (possibly a deity or ritual object) and "po‘o" (head) may allude to the *Ai Kapu* era’s emphasis on sacred objects and their transfer, where spiritual power was guarded and passed through specific rituals. This could symbolize the collapse of rigid kapu systems, as Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s actions might represent a break from traditional constraints.
raw_response:
<translation>The prayer of Nāmakaokapāo‘o was completed at that time, when he sought the ko‘ilipi on the pono of Nāmakaokapāo‘o, to transfer the sacredness of the ko‘i to Puali‘i, the island of the sacred, and speak from another place. The head of Puali‘i was placed upon Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Hello to you, O Nāmakaokapāo‘o.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o also served the head of Puali‘i and the kai of Waipouli, which is in the area of Honouliuli, his loa, five miles the loa.</translation>  

<commentary>  
**Paragraph 9:**  
• This passage describes a ritualistic or symbolic act involving the transfer of sacredness ("‘oi") and the placement of a "po‘o" (head) onto Nāmakaokapāo‘o, reflecting themes of spiritual authority and ancestral connections. The phrase "e ho‘ohuli aku ā nā ‘oi o ke ko‘i iā Puali‘i" suggests a deliberate act of transferring sacred power from the "ko‘i" (possibly a deity or ritual object) to Puali‘i, emphasizing the interplay between human and divine realms.  
• "Ko‘ilipi" and "kai o Waipouli" are likely place names, with "kai" (sea/coast) and "po‘o" (head) serving as symbolic markers of sacred geography. "Honouliuli" is a known historical region in O‘ahu, linking the narrative to specific Hawaiian cultural landscapes.  
• The dialogue “Aloha ‘oe, e Nāmakaokapāo‘o” (Hello to you, O Nāmakaokapāo‘o) mirrors traditional Hawaiian greetings that acknowledge both the speaker’s identity and the sacredness of the recipient, possibly signifying a rite of passage or spiritual recognition.  
• The phrase “five miles the loa” may allude to the "loa" (sacred or long) as a metaphor for distance or spiritual reach, tying to the concept of *mo‘olele* (distance) in Hawaiian cosmology. It could also reference the *loa* (spirits) in ancestral veneration, where physical proximity (e.g., five miles) symbolizes a boundary between the living and the spiritual.  
• The act of "pane mai ke po‘o o Puali‘i" (placing the head of Puali‘i) may allegorically represent the acceptance of responsibility or the embodiment of a deity’s power. In Hawaiian tradition, the "po‘o" (head) is a symbol of leadership and divine authority, suggesting Nāmakaokapāo‘o is now spiritually empowered by Puali‘i.  
• The mention of "kai o Waipouli" (sea of Waipouli) and "kahakai o Honouliuli" (area of Honouliuli) highlights the significance of coastal and valley regions in Hawaiian mythology, often associated with *mo‘okūau* (sacred sites) and ancestral journeys.  
• The structure of the sentence mirrors earlier examples in the text, where names are broken into poetic components (e.g., "Nāmakaokapāo‘o" as *Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o*, "the eyes of the pāo‘o fish"), reinforcing the tradition of *kī‘ōpae* (proverbial expressions) and *mele* (chant) in Hawaiian storytelling.  
• The reference to "ko‘i" (possibly a deity or ritual object) and "po‘o" (head) may allude to the *Ai Kapu* era’s emphasis on sacred objects and their transfer, where spiritual power was guarded and passed through specific rituals. This could symbolize the collapse of rigid kapu systems, as Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s actions might represent a break from traditional constraints.  
</commentary>
reference_translation: When Nāmakaokapāo‘o ended his prayer, Puali‘i  struck at Nāmakaokapāo‘o with the adze right on  top of his head, but the blade of the adze turned  towards Puali‘i and his head was cut off. From a  distance, the head of Puali‘i said to   Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Goodbye, Nāmakaokapāo‘o.”  Nāmakaokapāo‘o took the head of Puali‘i and  threw it in the sea at Waipouli, a cave on the  beach at Honouliuli, which was five miles long.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 9:**• While the abandonment of the ‘Ai Kapu and the rise  of Christianity are historical, Pua-li‘i’s attack of Nā- maka-o-ka-pāo‘o does not seem to have a correlating  historical reference. The ‘Ai Kapu was abandoned in  1819 and the first Christian missionaries arrived in  Hawai‘i in 1820, with a full year in the interum of no  organized religion to replace the ‘Ai Kapu. While  many Hawaiians were stubbon to adopt Christianity  and resented it, Christianity spread quickly and  overwhelmed any pro-‘Ai Kapu sentiment by the end  of the 1820s. If Pua-li‘i here represents the ‘Ai Kapu  and Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o represents Christianity, and  the adoption of Western culture in a more broad  sense, this event in the story seems to misrepresent  the ‘Ai Kapu as savage, impulsive, and violent against  Christianity, culminating in a single event. There is no  such historical single event recorded in history;  • By a twist of fate, the adze Pua-li‘i wielded to cut off  the head of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o somehow turned  against the wielder, cutting off the head of Pua-li‘i,  which Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o tossed into the ocean at Wai-pouli (water of darkness), a cave in Hono-uliuli  (bay of darkness) in ‘Ewa, O‘ahu, a distance of five   miles away. This ironic demise of Pua-li‘i signifies the  ultimate defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu by Christianity and/or  progressive ambitions, but this violent event has no  parallel in Hawaiian history. This could be viewed as  an embellishment as a type of Christian progaganda.  • The five-mile long toss of Pua-li‘i’s head by  Nāmakaokapāo‘o was an emphasis on the boy’s  superhuman physical strength.
